channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19 alert level 3: Schools prepare to resume classes
item.description: Teachers are getting ready for students to return to classes as the country moves to Covid-19 alert level 3.

item.title: Covid-19 live updates from New Zealand and around the world on 27 April
item.description: The Chinese city of Wuhan, where the global coronavirus pandemic began, now has no remaining cases in its hospitals. Follow the latest updates here.

item.title: South Island road crashes leave seven injured overnight
item.description: Several people were injured in a spate of serious crashes in the South Island late last night.

item.title: Building firms gear up to reopen tomorrow under alert level 3
item.description: Building firms are preparing to return to work tomorrow - albeit somewhat differently - as the country moves down to Covid-19 alert level 3 at 11.59pm tonight.

item.title: Invercargill considers rates relief
item.description: The Invercargill City Council is considering becoming the latest local authority to offer rates relief to those affected by the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: DHBs take outpatient appointments online
item.description: District health boards say that by using digital technology, they have processed thousands of outpatient appointments that would have been cancelled during the lockdown.

item.title: Covid-19: Union worries fast food outlets may breach level 3 restrictions
item.description: A union is worried that some major takeaway outlets could breach Covid-19 alert level 3 restrictions, with their plans to serve customers next week.

item.title: Covid 19: What happened in New Zealand on 26 April
item.description: An extra $107.6 million to help house the vulnerable both during and after the pandemic was announced today, there were nine new cases of Covid-19 and hopes that reopening garden centres will improve mental health.

item.title: Covid-19: Nine more cases, no new deaths
item.description: New Zealand has identified another nine cases of the Covid-19 coronavirus, and no new deaths.

item.title: NZ's responses to Covid-19 and polio vastly different
item.description: New Zealand has adopted the right approach to Covid-19 - despite trade and travel continuing during the waves of polio that hit the country in the 20th century, epidemiologist Michael Baker says.

item.title: Whangārei rates to be used towards likely $3m council Covid-19 relief
item.description: Whangārei District Council is looking to set up a $3 million Covid-19 relief package using ratepayers' money.

item.title: Caution advised for investors eyeing property market
item.description: A property investor says property shortages are likely if the economy goes into recession because of the Covid-19 crisis.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates from NZ and around the world on 26 April
item.description: Police are urging people to stick with the level 4 lockdown laws for another day. See how the rest of the day's news unfolded with RNZ's blog.

item.title: Lack of social connectedness with elderly a big concern - Research NZ
item.description: Nearly 80 percent of New Zealanders are concerned about the lack of physical contact with relatives, particularly the elderly, a new report shows.

item.title: Garden centres reopening under level 3 will help mental health - industry body
item.description: The return to alert level 3 means garden centres will be reopening, although with contactless service.

item.title: Government announces $100m for housing homeless
item.description: The government has announced an extra $107.6 million to help vulnerable people in need of housing.

item.title: Struggling fishing industry must be monitored, Forest and Bird warns
item.description: The downturn in fishing caused by the Covid-19 emergency could lead the industry to take environmentally damaging shortcuts warns Forest and Bird, but the seafood industry is defending its practices during the crisis.

item.title: NZNO nurses union president Grant Brookes resigns
item.description: The head of the Nurses Organisation has resigned because of deep divisions in the union, he says.
